 ECUADOR AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH PROJECT 1. COUNTRY AND SECTOR BACKGROUND A. Macroeconomic Context 1.1 Prior to 1992, Ecuador discriminated against agriculture for most of thirty years, as it followed an import substitution model of industrialization for economic development. The effects of this policy, which included high tariffs, subsidized interest rates and an expansionary fiscal policy, were accentuated by the petroleum boom of the 1970s that led to an overvalued exchange rate. The net result was that the model subsidized industry and urban dwellers, and discriminated heavily against agriculture and rural areas. Certain compensatory measures, such as subsidized credit, public sector irrigation and mechanization subsidies benefited only a small group of select farmers. 1.2 The present Government has implemented a series of macroeconomic policy reforms, building on thoseintroduced by Governments in the 1980s.1 Tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade have been reduced substantially or removed, interest rates are market determined, exchange rates are allowed to fluctuate, energy prices have been increased, privatization of Government enterprises has started, and the Government has followed a more conservative fiscal policy. In all, over 30,000 public sector jobs have been eliminated. 1.3 The Government also has implemented some sectoral policy reforms for agriculture, based on a program of modernization of the public sector. The state system of agricultural price supports has been eliminated, except for a few export crops, and storage silos sold or leased out. A new Agrarian Law has been passed which will make land and water markets more efficient, and which eliminates the outdated land reform law. IERAC (now INDA), the land titling agency, is in the process of being restructured. Restrictions on agricultural exports have been removed. Irigation policy has been reformed with; the substantial downsizing of INERHI, the regionalization of public projects, the shifting of operation and maintenance of public systems to private water users, and the introduction of mechanisms for greater cost recovery. In the area of agricultural research, through a law passed by Congress in 1992, the National Institute for Agriculture and Livestock Research (INIAP) was awarded administrative autonomy and access to an endowment fund paid for by the National Treasury. Both the IDB and the World Bank have strongly supported all of these reforms through the IDB Sector Loan, and the World Bank Technical Assistance Project for Irrigation.  2 1.4 However, reforms to the sector are still not complete. Reference prices are still being maintained for exports of coffee, cacao and bananas. ENAC still is involved in price supports through the market for CDs. Water rights can only be transferred with land, unless there is specific Government approval. And several Government agencies still need to be restructured or privatized. 1.5 The net effect of the macroeconomic and sectoral reforms, referred to above, is to increase incentives for agriculture and thereby create the conditions for it to be a dynamic and sustainable contributor to the overall economy. This in turn, will provide a much more positive basis upon which the modernization of the agricultural research system can proceed. These changes will put new demands on the system and it's on this basis that the project is designed. B. Agriculture in the Economy 1.6 Agriculture is still the dominant sector of the Ecuadoran economy. In 1994 it accounted for 17 percent of GDP, 33 percent of foreign exchange earnings, and is the major source of employment in the economy accounting for 35 percent of formal and the bulk of informal employment. After a period of slow growth prior to 1980, the sector has shown impressive growth over the past decade and a half, having risen from 13.2 percent in 1980 to 17 percent of GDP in 1994. However, physical growth came almost exclusively from an expansion in area. Yield data for the seven principal crops show that the average growth in production, between 1980 and 1992 was 3.58 percent per annum, with area expansion at 4.55 percent and yields declining at a rate of -0.93 percent per annum.2 The growth in animal production is also reflected in the increase in the area dedicated to pastures, which has increased from 2.1 million ha in 1974 to 4.9 million ha in 1992. 1.7 Ecuadoran agriculture in general is characterized by low yields. A comparison with Colombia, where the range of crops and growing conditions are similar, shows yields of the main crops in Ecuador ranging from 52 percent to 27 percent lower than those in Colombia. Even in the case of its main export crop, bananas, technology levels fall will behind that of its main competitors. Under this scenario, with land productivity declining and available land resources diminishing, the development strategy must be changed to a "science-based" approach concentrating on the improvement of the productivity of sustainable agricultural systems. This will be the challenge of this project. 2 Ecuador - Agricultural Sector Review 1992.
 3 C. Agricultural Institutions and Services Research 1.8 This activity is carried out by INIAP, universities and the private sector. Annual expenditure is calculated at about US$7.4 million, with about 200 scientists being engaged in conducting, supporting and managing research. 1.9 INIAP which was founded in 1959 as the research institute of the Ministry of Agriculture has been the prime recipient of public funds for agricultural research. It has seven research stations and a number of experimental farms and conducts research on about thirty different crop and livestock species. Part of its land is used for seed production and commercial farming. Over the years, from being a well-focused organization that produced good results, it developed into a very weak organization that maintained little of its original objectives. From the foundation of INIAP up to 1975, public investments in agricultural research increased steadily, reaching a high of 0.85 percent of AgGDP in 1975. This level of investment compared very favorably with that of other LAC countries. However, since then, public investments have been drastically reduced and were only 0.25 percent of AgGDP in 1992. The result was a serious decline in INIAPs executive and scientific capacity. Simultaneously, due to political pressures it expanded its program beyond its budgetary capacity, reducing its operational funds and making it very unattractive for good researchers to stay. 1.10 To overcome this downward spiral the Congress approved a law in 1992 giving INIAP administrative autonomy. Along with this autonomy it was assigned by law an endowment fund of approximately US$10 million. This endowment fund is to be added to yearly by the National Treasury. This autonomy - although the institute is still almost totally dependent for its budget on the MAG - has brought many changes to the organization. It has set its own salary scale, has reduced its personnel by about 30 percent and is now developing a new set of research priorities. This is an ongoing process with the objective of a smaller, better focused and more relevant institution. Following the recent downsizing INIAP has six Ph.D., 65 M.S., and 123 other graduates (including those in training) in a total staff of 433. Its 1995 budget is of the order of US$4.2 million (see Annex 3). 1.11 In the case of universities, most have limited research equipment, lands and libraries. Although there are 25 faculties of agricultural and veterinary science, many faculty are part-time and of a total of 1,253 professional staff in 1992, only 70 had M.S. degrees and nine had Ph.Ds. In theory, university research should be well funded by the National Council for Universities (CONUEP) which is supposed to receive one percent of GDP for research grants. In practice the Government has never met this obligation and in 1992 CONUEP received only US$1.3 million or under 0.01 percent of GDP. About 20 percent of this is allocated for projects in the agriculture sector. In
 4 addition to CONUEP funds, some universities have been able to solicit funds from international and local sources. These are usually for small projects (see Annex 3). 1.12 The participation of the private sector in the generation of technology has been increasing in recent years. It now funds and executes research in a variety of commodities, such as maize, banana, coffee, palm oil, horticultural crops, flowers, milk processing and a variety of other activities. These activities are concentrated in the applied end of the research spectrum such as the development of hybrid seeds, field testing of agrochemical, in vitro reproduction of plant materials, etc., and are an important source of ready to use technology. A recent study4 of private sector agricultural research identified nine organizations that were involved in some depth, with 22 professionals and 24 technicians, including three Ph.Ds and M.Scs. These are much smaller numbers of researchers than at INIAP although their estimated 1991 annual budget (US$3.1 million) was 75 percent as large. This was attributable to better salaries and a much higher technician to researcher ratio. Research is also being carried out in Ecuador by foreign research institutes (e.g., CIRAD, CIP, CIAT), usually in collaboration with INIAP and is often funded by donors such as COTESU, USAID or IDRC (CEOD). 1.13 Farmers associations have not as yet been an important source of financing for agricultural research. They usually place more emphasis on policy activities where they defend the interests of their associates. However in some cases they have financed agricultural extension in a very limited way. The Government is currently processing new legislation to promote the formation of producer associations (gremios) and this could have a mraor influence on the direction of research in the future. Financial support from farmers will be critical for the long-term sustainability of the research system, because it is through such support that farmers research needs can be expressed, leading to a more demand-driven system. Extension 1.14 Public agricultural extension in Ecuador exists since 1945, having been financed under a variety of programs and donors. In recent times the largest effort in this area has been the Agricultural and Livestock Technology Development Program (PROTECA), which had an extension component, and which was financed by the Inter- American Development Bank (IDB) and executed by MAG. This project terminated in September 1994. This program financed about 500 public extensionists to give technical assistance to about 85,000 small and medium sized farmers. However, the MAG has not institutionalized the system and when the project finished there were about 400 trained extensionists available to be employed in other activities. 1.15 Besides PROTECA there have been other donor funded projects in agricultural extension such as: the Research, Extension and Education Project funded by 4 Falcoi, Ccsa A. 1992, Public and Private Sector Interactions in Agricultural Research in Less- Developed Countries: The Case ofEcuador. For the past thirty years, many NGOs, both national and international have been active in the area of agricultural extension. These organizations have worked with the poorest farmers in the marginal areas. 1.16 IDB has prepared an agricultural extension project, as a part of the Modernization of Agricultural Services Program, which also includes this project. It aims to increase the participation of the private sector by contracting implementation of the project to private firms and in the case of competitive agriculture by introducing cost recovery mechanisms which in the long run should lead to greater private sector participation in the financing of the service. Plant and Animal Health 1.17 These activities are presently executed by specific programs within MAG under the direction of the Technical Subsecretary. Present activities of the Government are concentrated in the areas of import and export quarantine, control of the movement of animal and vegetable products, disease and pest control programs, register and control of agriculture and veterinary products, diagnostic laboratories, control of packing houses and the inspection of meat and other agricultural products. These services have been characterized by the lack of operating budget and adequately trained personnel. Because of this, the results have not been very good, with the entry of new pests and diseases adding to the problems caused by the traditional endemic ones. There have been other complications such as an increase in the residues of antibiotics, pesticides and other contaminants found in food supplies. EDB has prepared a project for the establishment of a new national Plant and Animal Health Service, as part of the Modernization of Agricultural Services Program. 2. AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH A. Research Expenditures 2.1 The greater part of agricultural research in Ecuador is funded by the public sector. Public expenditure on agricultural research can be justified for a number of reasons, the three principal ones being: "market failure" because firms or individuals cannot capture sufficient benefits to justify the investment; natural resource research which benefits all of society; and social equity. As Ecuador looks to the future and the need to increase its investments in agricultural research, neither the public nor the private sectors alone will be capable of responding to the research needs of the sector. One of the
 6 challenges will be to develop funding systems that use both public and private resources in an efficient way. 2.2 Public investments in agricultural research (in INIAP and the universities) have declined steadily in real terms since 1975. Public research expenditures as a share of AgGDP also declined steadily after 1975 and were only .25 percent in 1993 compared to a high of .85 percent in 1975. While no historical data are available on private sector investments in agricultural research, it is clear that the sector has increased its investments as Government support eroded. It is estimated that total (public plus private) research investment in 1993 to be US$7.4 million or .43 percent of AgGDP, which is only slightly above fifty percent of the level of public investment in 1975 (see Annex 3). 2.3 While there are empirical recommendations as to an appropriate level of investment in agricultural research there is no simple formula available to determine how much money should be invested and subjective judgment is relied on when making such decisions. This being the case, then an important criterion for Ecuador should be the level of investment of its competitors and short to medium term projections for investment should be brought in line with these levels. 2.4 Even with private sector research, Ecuador has made very limited investments in comparison to the rest of the developing world. Data for 52 developing countries showed an average investment in agricultural research of .94 percent of AgGDP during 1980-1985, up from .69 percent during 1970-1979. Thus, Ecuador sharply reduced its investments in agricultural research while most of its competitors were increasing their investments. Ecuador compares quite poorly with its regional trading partners in terms of investments in agricultural research. According to IDB, in 1993 Peru invested close to one percent of its AgGDP in agricultural research (not including private sector investments) or four times more than Ecuador. Colombia also invested more than Ecuador, at 0.5 percent of its AgGDP in 1991. These bordering countries are Ecuador most important competitors in the Andean Pact, both for lucrative export markets in the U.S. and Europe, and for provision of food and fiber supplies in the region. The fact that Peru and Colombia are investing so much more in agricultural research puts significant pressure on Ecuador to increase its investments and reform its research system (see Annex 3). B. Government Agricultural Technology Strategy Public Private Roles 2.5 Research activities are spread across a continuum that ranges from basic at one end through strategic and applied research to adaptive research at the other end. Depending on the appropriability of the results and the level of risk involved, private and public sectors can participate and interact along that continuum. Practice has shown that private sector efforts are more concentrated in the applied and adaptive end of the continuum whereas public funding focuses on basic and strategic research activities along
 7 with areas that have to do with social equity, poverty alleviation and the environment. In an effective system public and private research complement each other, because each sector is involved in different types of activities along the research spectrum. Historically, public investment has been the springboard for private involvement in research in developed countries. 2.6 It is generally accepted that in countries with the same level of development as Ecuador that there is a large public good component in agricultural research. However, as the economy develops further the private sector will participate to an increasing degree. It is important to define in principle the public good component of research and to have funding mechanisms in place that can respond to the system as it evolves to increasing private sector participation. 2.7 The strategy of the present Government is to revitalize the agricultural research system by; increasing overall funding and putting in place incentives, in the form of funding mechanisms, that will increase the participation of other organizations (private sector, universities and NGOs) both in the implementation and financing of research. C. Bank Experience in Agricultural Sector Lending 2.8 Bank projects in Ecuador have repeatedly encountered weaknesses in public sector management and coordination. These include excessive bureaucracy, inadequate personnel incentive structures, and shortages of trained people at all levels. The institutional capacity to absorb technical assistance is frequently limited. Leadership mandates are often superficial and/or fleeting and agency management turns over frequently. Projects require the explicit definition of issues and objectives during identification and preparation, and a tight focus on a limited number of components. Careful attention is needed to limiting the longer-term burden on the recurrent budget, and human resource development should be given high priority. Regular, intensive supervision is needed to keep components on track. 2.9 The Bank has supported and continues to support agricultural research in a number of ways; as freestanding research projects, as components in rural development projects, in education projects and in policy-based lending. Since the beginning of FY78 the Bank has been involved in freestanding research projects with total project costs of US$3.8 billion and a loan amount of US$1.7 billion. Research components in other projects have cost close to US$2.0 billion with a loan amount of US$0.5 billion. According to the OED database, the results have been relatively favorable with 78 percent rated as "satisfactory". Despite this positive rating common problems have been identified across the range of projects. These problems are; inadequate counterpart funding, overdimensioning in relation to prospective resources, lack of capacity to plan and set research priorities, and lack of demand driven research.
 8 3. THE PROJECT A. Origin and Rationale for World Bank Involvement 3.1 The 1992 Ecuador Agricultural Sector Review highlighted three broad problems facing the agricultural sector: (i) unrealized sectoral growth; (ii) deforestation and soil erosion from rapid expansion of the crop and livestock frontiers, raising serious concerns about the sustainability of sectoral growth; and (iii) acute and widespread rural poverty. This project addresses (i) and (ii) through strengthening the agricultural research system so as to increase productivity and thereby have more efficient growth and less exploitation of the natural resource base. While it is not a direct poverty intervention it has important implications for rural poverty as the research priorities, i. e., rice, potatoes, maize, etc., being financed under the project are of importance to small farmers as illustrated in the recent Poverty Report (June 30, 1995). As the project is expected to increase agricultural productivity it will also increase economic opportunities in rural areas and halt the deterioration of the natural resource base which is tightly linked to rural poverty. Through increased food production it will also maintain an adequate supply of cheap food for poor consumers. This project is fully consistent with the CAS that is being presented to the Board on April 4, 1996, and would support three of the broad objectives for Ecuador: poverty alleviation, by focusing research on basic food commodities grown by resource poor farmers; institutional strengthening, by modernizing INRAP through its Development Plan; and private sector development, by opening research funding to a range of institutions, including foundations, universities and NGOs. 3.2 The project is a component of the Modernization of Agricultural Services Program by the Ministry of Agriculture. The other two components, Technology Transfer and Plant and Animal Health are being financed separately by IDB for a total project cost of US$41 million (paras. 1.16 and 1.17). The overall program which will be managed by the Project Implementation Unit within MAG, is aimed at strengthening the range of public services needed for a modern and competitive agricultural sector. 3.3 The justification for public investments in agricultural research is that some of the results of such an activity are public goods. Private agents do not have the full incentives to invest in such goods. Public subsidies, rather than full cost recovery from agricultural producers benefiting from research are also justified, because benefits from such research flow to consumers and the environment. They flow to consumers via long- term commodity price decreases which affect the poorer classes disproportionately in a beneficial way, and the environment benefits through more efficient use of natural resources. This latter is very important in Ecuador as most of its agricultural growth in the last fifteen years has come from expanding area under cultivation and pastures thereby increasing erosion and lowering biodiversity. Under the economic framework of more open markets and increased trade, Ecuador will be under increased pressure to modernize its agriculture and compete internationally. Because of new developments in science, of which the country has not taken advantage for at least fifteen years, and the present low productivity levels (see Annex 3), the agricultural research system is presented with new
 9 demands and also opportunities to lead the sector in renewed and efficient growth. This project will assist in orienting this public investment to more efficient uses in line with the Governments objectives for agricultural research. 3.4 Support for the project is also warranted on the basis of past results. Although support for agricultural research has unstable and declining over the past twenty years in Ecuador, the system has been successful in general and in some areas has made major contributions. Joint research on rice by INIAP, universities and international agencies resulted in returns of 34 percent between 1970 and 1990. A series of related studies carried out by INIAP with support from ISNAR and FUNDAGRO revealed the following rates of return to research investments: hard corn, 70 percent; African palm, 32 percent; potatoes, 33 percent; soybeans, 17 percent; and wheat, 29 percent.5 An economic evaluation of both research and extension, the latter being financed by IDB, was carried out as part of the initial preparation. This study gave an internal rate of return of 44.5 percent based on certain assumptions as to changes in productivity and prices. There are limitations on the validity of such an evaluation, since not all productivity increases can be attributed directly to research and extension alone, and the assumptions are based on data from past experience. The full results of the economic evaluation are available in the project file (Annex 11). B. Economic Evaluation 3.5 Economic analysis for the project has been carried out to test its economic viability. A multiple criteria model has been utilized in light of the fact that agricultural research is focused upon different objectives such as: economic growth, distribution of income and sustainability; multiple criteria models seem to be more appropriate to evaluate the attainment of different objectives. The model used (MODEXC, developed in 1990 by the International Center for Tropical Agriculture) is a partial equilibrium model which evaluates the direct benefits of new technology and associated income distribution results. 3.6 The social benefits and costs for each technological option are estimated and benefits of each technology are distributed among specific activities (such as genetic improvements or new fertilization systems). This process allows estimation of economic efficiency for each activity. 3.7 The selection of commodities considered under the analysis is based on the relative weight that each commodity holds in the gross national agricultural product (GNAP). The GNAP used in this case represents the average for years 1991 through 1993. The result is a group of 16 products that accounts for over 90 percent of the total aggregate value of domestic production. Based on INIAP historical data, average annual growth rate and price projections are estimated for each commodity (see Annex 4 for 5 INIAP 1993 Retorno a las Inversiones en Investigacidn Agropecuaria Quito: Direccidn de Planificaci6n.
 10 details). These projections have been incorporated in the economic model in order to estimate overall technology benefits. 3.8 Assumptions regarding the following have also been included in the model: (a) exogenous growth and demand rates for commodities; (b) the consumption structure of commodities relative to beneficiary incomes; (c) farm data representative of beneficiaries; (d) yields of new and present technologies; (e) the time required to implement and adopt new technologies; (f) the area to which new technologies are applied; (g) research required to obtain new technologies and the probability of success for such research; and (h) research and technology costs. This data allows for the estimation of increased production because of technological change and its adoption by farmers. This is purely technical information, taken directly at INIAP's research stations, from interviews with different commodity research specialists. 3.9 Based on the above, the model estimates producers and consumer surpluses, separating those that can be ascribed to technological factors. The benefits ascribed to the project are estimated to be only thirty percent of the surpluses, multiplied by the probability of success (about 75 to 80 percent) for each technology through the research and transfer process. As demonstrated in Annex 4, net benefits from the project are estimated at nearly US$176 million in year 15. Considering benefit flows for all years and the project costs, the NPV for the project is estimated at about US$389 million, using a discount rate of 12 percent. The ERR is estimated at 52 percent. These results are in line with numerous ex post studies regarding the impact of agriculture research and technology projects in Latin America and worldwide. 3.10 In addition to the overall project benefits estimation, the impact of technology application on international trade has been measured. Trade would improve significantly, considering that most commodities under the analysis can be exported. Based on the consolidated results of MODEXC, it is estimated that the trade surplus for these products could grow by 49 percent in the year 2000 and at the end of the project it could more than triple. 3.11 Finally, sensitivity analysis has been carried out for the project to test the impact of either overall income decreases or increases. As shown in Annex 4, by decreasing benefits such that income resulting from the project fall by 20 percent, the estimated internal rate of return would decline by eight percent. This represents a reduction in the NPV of about US$95 million. Because of the relatively high NPV and return benefits would have to fall by over 80 percent to obtain an NPV of zero. A 20 percent increase in overall costs yields similar NPV and IRR results. To obtain an NPV of zero, costs would have to increase by nearly six times. While these results show that project returns are sensitive to movements in overall benefits and costs, the returns are high enough that a 20 percent unfavorable shift in either benefits or costs would not produce negative overall results.

Project Objectives 3.12 The objective is to strengthen the national capacity to do agricultural research, with an aim to increase agricultural productivity and output while preserving or enhancing the natural resource base, by: (i) introducing a competitive research grant program; (ii) developing Research and Education Exchange partnerships with intemational science institutions; and (iii) strengthening the national agricultural research institute, NIAP. D. Project Description A Diversfied, Interactive and Competitive System 3.13 To achieve the above objectives this project proposes to put in place a new technology generation system for Ecuador. The project will create a research capacity within the country that will result in a diversified, and interactive and sustainable research system. Increasing or diversifying the number of suppliers of technology will by itself bring more resources into the system and will provide a broader opportunity for private funding sources to participate, thereby contributing to the sustainability of the system. Through the competitive funding grants, opportunities will be provided for joint research projects to be developed between research entities (research institutes, universities, NGOs etc.), and the private sector. Giving the opportunity to farmers groups to cofinance such projects will strengthen their ownership of the research system, along with their participation on the executive council and their involvement in the discussions for priority setting. 3.14 In the past, little has been done to encourage the integration of the three main groups, INLAP, universities and farmers groups, that effectively make up the national agricultural research system (NARS) in Ecuador. This all-inclusive concept of a NARS is one of the underlying principles of this project. The project will incorporate the largest number of research and interest groups as possible. This will help to assure that all aspects of needed research can be covered and that the products will provide answers for most relevant economic, social and environmental problems. 3.15 Another principle underlying this project is that of interaction. A modem agricultural research system requires regular interaction among the various institutional participants and scientists. Linkages between farmers and researchers need to be clearly articulated, efficient and regular. Farmers must be able to communicate their concerns to researchers quickly and systematically. Through participation in competitive funding mechanisms farmers will be able to influence the research agenda. The various research institutions must be able to affiliate with each other and work closely together in joint research programs, when circumstances warrant. The project through special funding mechanisms will develop these linkages and promote joint research programs between institutions that will allow them to work together when their collective resources are better able to resolve a problem than individual efforts (see Annex 4).
 12 3.16 Another principle underlying this project is competition, which is a required element for efficient production of new technical knowledge. The project will utilize the concept of competition as the basis for allocating scarce research resources among individual researchers and among research institutions. This will allow the system to be more responsive to the needs of farmers and be more demand driven. Research Priorities 3.17 Sectoral policy for agriculture in Ecuador encompasses the broad issues of equity, efficiency, food security and natural resource conservation. When INIAP was established in the mid-sixties its work program revolved around a set of priorities, which were developed within the framework of national food self-sufficiency and thereby concentrated on the basic food commodities. However, over the years the list of priorities was added to indiscriminately through political pressure, and by researchers who set their own research agenda. 3.18 In recent years, INIAP has sponsored in collaboration with ISNAR two priority setting exercises to improve the objectivity of research resource allocation. For the preparation of this project Fundacion IDEA used an economic surplus model developed at CIAT (Colombia) to suggest research priorities. Although these three studies resulted in somewhat different specific rankings of priorities there was a high level of congruency between all studies when the top ten priorities were taken as a group. The studies were also consistent in emphasizing that the most important commodities are those from the coastal region. This reflects the change in agricultural production over the past thirty years. These priorities have now been accepted by the MAG for funding under the project (Annex 6). This exercise in priority setting should be regarded as an iterative process of dialogue arnong all the interested parties; producers, Government, and research organizations in order to have the flexibility to modify priorities as circumstances demand. 3.19 INIAP has used its priority setting exercises to establish a research progran based on nine national, four regional programs and seven technical departments. The nine national programs are: cattle and pastures, rice, corn, roots and tubers, coffee, cacao, bananas and plantains, fruits, legumes and agroforestry. The four regional programs are: Andean grains, soya, small grain cereals, and swine. The seven technical departments are: soil and water, pest management, genetic resources, nutrition, biometrics, economics and planning, and information. 3.20 Since the most important problems that have to be solved are of a practical nature the research agenda to be financed under this project will concentrate on the applied and adaptive end of the research spectrum. There will also be a strong orientation towards products that make up the bulk of small farm production, such as plantains, rice, potatoes, maize, coffee and cacao. Natural resource management research, i.e., soil and water management, genetic resources, and pest management will also be funded.

The research system suffers from several basic problems which all tend to derive from inadequate funding for agricultural research. Because INIAP has dominated the system for the last three decades most of the problems relate to INIAP. Some of the constraints, however, relate to weaknesses in universities, and lack of cohesiveness in the system. 16. Too Few Research Scientists. Ecuador has significantly underinvested in research scientists (ISNAR and IICA pp. 3943); (Venezian and Moncada pp. 29-30)16. Several areas especially lack research scientists in Ecuador, including animal sciences, natural resources, agricultural economics, rural sociology, biotechnology, and irrigation sciences. 17. Inadequate Salaries. The principal constraint to attracting and retaining agricultural scientists during the 1980s has been the relatively low salaries offered. As budget support declined, INIAP lost four out of five Ph.Ds and 18 of 67 Masters between 1986 and 1989, or nearly one-third of its senior scientists in a three-year period. While the situation has improved somewhat, LIAP continues to be plagued by turnover of research scientists. The underlying problem is limited funding for INIAP, universities and other research institutes and NGOs which are part of the system. Unless funding is increased, it will be very difficult to increase salaries to market levels, even if the problem of an inadequate salary scale were resolved. Resource constraints and poorly-trained faculty result in little laboratory or field work. Resources for higher education are spread too thin. What is needed is a more foased effort with substantial upgrading of a few key faculties of agriculture. A CRG Program operates on the principle that the system selects for scientific excellence by providing the Principle Investigator (PI), or the Project Director (PD) with adequate funding to enable research on a particular topic. The PI is the designated individual researcher responsible for preparing and submitting the research grant, and for carrying out the research plan. A PD is an individual researcher responsible for administering a group, or team, of researchers working on a specific research theme. For example, a PD would be the professional scientist in charge of a multidisciplinary, multi- institutional association of university, INLAP, NGO, and/or private sector laboratories. 3. The CRG Program encourages, and sometimes requires, multidisciplinary, multi-institutional associations or partnerships. For example, an individual research grant has one PI, but may have additional Co-PIs, or Contractors, from different disciplines and/or institutions. (Private sector research laboratories will be eligible to enter into partnerships with these entities and will be expected to provide appropriate matching support for the project.).

A Partnership Grant should not be looked upon as a permanent mechanism for the funding of a group of investigators, but as a mechanism that serves a particular purpose at a particular time in the scientific development of the Ecuadoran agricultural research community. It would be expected that some projects initiated under Partnership funding might evolve or expand in such a way as to warrant separate lines of support, while new Partnership projects would emerge to take their place. When a Partnership no longer fulfills the intended puipose, it would be expected to come to a natural end. As such time, support of ongoing research may, of course, be sought under the Competitive Research Grants Program. 22. "Sister" Institution Partnerships. There are a large number of models available for both informal and formal "sister" institutional alignments. The formation of an analogous networks can be organized in joint INIAP, university, private sector research partnerships with international institutions in Ecuador. Institutional Partnerships must be organized with great care and the "sister" institute must be fully aware of what is expected. In the case of universities, the Ecuadoran institution will cooperate with its "sister" institute in both student education and in laying the groundwork for a degree- granting Ecuadoran "institution" in agricultural services. 23. The task of training foreign graduate students is the traditional role of most "sister" institute partnerships. Graduate student training will begin in Ecuador in special introductory courses (in which appropriate "sister" institute adjunct faculty members will participate) followed by additional course work at the foreign "sister" institute or other appropriate institution. Once this course work is completed, students will return to their Ecuadoran institution. In the case of the Ph.D. candidate, to perform his/her research thesis work. Once the Ph.D. thesis research is completed to the satisfaction of both institutions, the degree candidate will return to the "sister" institute, or other appropriate institution, to defend the thesis in accord with the requirements for the degree of Ph.D. 24. The task of building a recognized award granting entity in Ecuador in agricultural research will be long-term as discussed earlier. At present, the Ecuadoran agricultural research community is small and does not have a critical number of Ph.D.- level personnel to grant a recognized graduate degree. This could begin to change, however, under favorable conditions that will allow for the Competitive Research Grants program to take affect, and which in turn should give employment for returning young
 59 Ph.D. researchers to Ecuador and provide them with the means to organize their own research programs. In keeping with this objective, the Ecuadoran university in its negotiations with a sister institute, must make the need clear for sharing in the responsibility of laying the groundwork for a graduate degree granting program in Ecuador through active faculty teaching/research commitments. 25. Applicants for advanced degree fellowships will be evaluated on their ability, accomplishments, and potential as evidenced by letters of recommendation; results on standardized graduate school entry examinations (as required by the admissions committee at a "sister" institution); the quality and significance of their proposed research topic; the cross-disciplinary potential of the research topic; and the likely impact of the proposed training and research on the applicant's future scientific development and long- range career goals. Applications will be reviewed by an advisory committee comprised of faculty members which includes adjunct faculty members. This advisory committee will make its recommendations to the NGO administering the competitive aspects of the project where final selection of graduate fellows will be made. The NGO will notify awardees within one month after the advisory committee recommendation, and immediately begin to lay plans, in consultation with the sponsoring Ecuadoran institution, for the student's advanced graduate training outside the country. This could include language training, as appropriate. 26. Administration of the Partnerships. To respond effectively to the research and educational needs of a growing Ecuadoran Agricultural Research Community, the duties of the MU officers must be far-reaching and their decisions should be viewed as being informed and just. L Background Data and Justification Agricultural policy management in the closing years of the twentieth century does not have the same roots and purposes as in the early 1900s. The circumstances have changed drastically, especially if the situation as it was then is compared with the 1950s and 1960s when the so-called "Green revolution " was at its height. The flow of events has caused successive governments to take steps aimed primarily at meeting domestic supply needs and including adoption of measures designed to ensure responsible use and control of renewable natural resources. For a while, the public sectors concern did not go beyond obtaining higher productivity and profitability, so that emphasis was placed on the research and extension services as a means for harnessing the potentials offered by technological development. However, this policy proved inadequate as the years passed. The social changes and pressures, the deterioration of the environment as a result of overuse and poor management of natural and technological resources, the variable behavior of the market in the vast field formed by a supply and demand extending beyond the national borders and the demands for larger incomes expressed by the various actors in the agriculture sector gave rise to a more complex and less linear approach to the problems noted.
 62 Accordingly, generation and transfer of technology and the establishment of a price policy with a view to increasing productivity and improving profitability are no longer the only goals, but steps are envisaged for upgrading product quality, ensuring appropriate use of agricultural chemnicals and biological agents to reduce toxicity and pollution levels in persons and the environment, locating and delirmiting crops in light of their agroecological and commercial possibilities, conserving natural resources by means of appropriate use and providing the infrastructure and services necessary for the production, conservation and transportation of agrolivestock and forestry products. In this context, the strategies to be employed and the application of new know how, such as the organization and training of groups for self-nanagement purposes, design, dissemination and implementation of agrosylvopastoral systems and their derivatives, and the application of biotechnology, are also irnportant. In light of the foregoing, it will be readily apparent that the conceptual framework, for development purposes, of the agriculture sector has changed. Today production and productivity are not the only concems, but consideration is also given to return and sustainable managernent of the resources used in the production process, especially those connected with preservation of the environment. However, the promotion and implementation of all these activities are subject to the funds available, which is why all the needs cannot be met simultaneously in a given time period. Selection and prioritization are therefore called for, so that the results obtained will be real and highly beneficial, both from the economic standpoint and in the social and ecological spheres. IL Criteria and Procedures for Selection and Prioritization In accordance with the above, the Directorate of Planning formulated seven criteria that facilitated the selection and ranking of the crops and livestock on which the agricultural public sector will have to concentrate in the short and medium term. These criteria are the following: Area cultivated or total number of animals per species. Potential percentage increase in productivity. - Number of technologies available per crop or species of animal. - lInportance of the product in the family shopping basket. - Possibilities of exporting the product. - The products commercial perfonnance.

In addition, the National Agricultural Research Institute (anstituto Naciona de Investigaciones Agropecuarias - ILMP) has also produced for its own account a selection and prioritization of crops and livestock, based on the following criteria assigned appropriate weightings: - Effective demand for technology on the farmers' part. - Need for research. - Social importance of the item in terms of food supply. - Availability of technology for transfer. - Commercial potential. As is apparent, three of these five criteria coincide with those applied by the Ministry of Agriculture and Stockraising (MAG). Finally, the Directorate of Research, Technology Transfer and Extension has drawn up its own list using criteria similar to those detailed above. At a meeting organized by the Directorate of Planning to agree on priorities as regards crops and livestock, a committee was appointed to harnonize the various criteria used by the agencies referred to aad to draw up a definitive and official list for the Ministry of Agriculture and Stockraising. The committee was made up of representatives of the Directorates of Planning, Agricultural Information and Renewable Natural Resources, and of Research, Technology Transfer and Extension. The procedure foliowed by the committee in establishing the priorities was to compare the three lists available and to rank the crops and livestock in accordance with those placing highest in the three lists, while those shown as least priority are those which only featured in one of them, plus some others that the committee considered on account of certain factors analyzed in the relevant session. doc.abstracts: The principal objective of this Agricultural Research Project for Ecuador is to strengthen the national capacity to conduct agricultural research, with the aim of increasing agricultural productivity and output while preserving or enhancing the natural resource base, by: (i) introducing a competitive research grant program; (ii) developing research and education exchange partnerships with international science institutions; and (iii) strengthening the national agricultural research institute, INIAP. The project components include: (i) competitive grants which include research grants, research and educational exchange partnerships with international institutions; (ii) strengthening INIAP; and (iii) project implementation.
